content.text: TypeScript Introduction
TypeScript is JavaScript with added syntax for types.
content.html: TypeScript is JavaScript with added syntax for types.

content.text: What is TypeScript?
TypeScript is a syntactic superset of JavaScript which adds static typing .
content.html: TypeScript is a syntactic superset of JavaScript which adds static typing.

content.text: This basically means that TypeScript adds syntax on top of JavaScript, allowing developers to add types .
content.html: This basically means that TypeScript adds syntax on top of JavaScript, allowing developers to add types.

content.text: TypeScript being a "Syntactic Superset" means that it shares the same base syntax as JavaScript, but adds something to it.
content.html: TypeScript being a "Syntactic Superset" means that it shares the same base syntax as JavaScript, but adds something to it.

content.text: Why should I use TypeScript?
JavaScript is a loosely typed language. It can be difficult to understand what types of data are being passed around in JavaScript.
content.html: JavaScript is a loosely typed language. It can be difficult to understand what types of data are being passed around in JavaScript.

content.text: In JavaScript, function parameters and variables don't have any information! So developers need to look at documentation, or guess based on the implementation.
content.html: In JavaScript, function parameters and variables don't have any information! So developers need to look at documentation, or guess based on the implementation.

content.text: TypeScript allows specifying the types of data being passed around within the code, and has the ability to report errors when the types don't match.
content.html: TypeScript allows specifying the types of data being passed around within the code, and has the ability to report errors when the types don't match.

content.text: For example, TypeScript will report an error when passing a string into a function that expects a number. JavaScript will not.
content.html: For example, TypeScript will report an error when passing a string into a function that expects a number. JavaScript will not.

content.text: TypeScript uses compile time type checking. Which means it checks if the specified types match before running the code, not while running the code.
content.html: TypeScript uses compile time type checking. Which means it checks if the specified types match before running the code, not while running the code.

content.text: How do I use TypeScript?
A common way to use TypeScript is to use the official TypeScript compiler, which transpiles TypeScript code into JavaScript.
content.html: A common way to use TypeScript is to use the official TypeScript compiler, which transpiles TypeScript code into JavaScript.

content.text: The next section shows how to get the compiler setup for a local project.
content.html: The next section shows how to get the compiler setup for a local project.

content.text: Some popular code editors, such as Visual Studio Code, have built-in TypeScript support and can show errors as you write code!
content.html: Some popular code editors, such as Visual Studio Code, have built-in TypeScript support and can show errors as you write code!
